with

Note that this definition takes a long time to elaborate (maxHeartbeats set to 300000).

Note what looks to me to be a related question here. The key part of error says

all remaining arguments have metavariables:
  SetLike ?Ïƒ' A
  @AddSubmonoidClass ?Ïƒ' A AddMonoid.toAddZeroClass ?instâœ
  @SetLike.GradedMonoid Î¹ A ?Ïƒ' ?instâœ MonoidWithZero.toMonoid instâœÂ¹Â¹ ?ğ“

This is the situation that typeclass inference finds itself in. It hasn't figured out how what type you actually want Ïƒ' to be. This is funny because you can read Ïƒ' off from the type of the first explicit input, but I have no idea in what order things happen when the system is doing all this unification and typeclass inference stuff. And what it's really trying to put off is using typeclass inference on any of the above goals, because it might end up in a loop or searching in a very large tree for something that isn't there.

Oh there are two similar errors: the second one has shorter output.

  @SetLike.GradedMonoid Î¹ A Ïƒ' instâœâ¹ MonoidWithZero.toMonoid instâœÂ¹Â¹ ?ğ“

So this indicates that the system doesn't know what ğ“ is but now needs to know that whatever it is, it's a graded ring, and that will make typeclass inference go on a wild goose chase.

I think this translates down to the following statement:

def is_module [decidable_eq Î¹] [graded_ring ğ“] :

If typeclass inference gets its hands on this declaration then it realises that it will have to figure out what ğ“ is in order to check it's a graded ring, but it has no hope. Hopefully the experts will fix which parts of the explanation I mangled.
It might have just been an unnoticed dangerous instance in Lean 3

Yeah the Lean 3 linter has the following to say about that instance:

/- The `dangerous_instance` linter reports: -/
/- DANGEROUS INSTANCES FOUND.
These instances are recursive, and create a new type-class problem which will have metavariables.
Possible solution: remove the instance attribute or make it a local instance instead.

Currently this linter does not check whether the metavariables only occur in arguments marked with `out_param`, in which case this linter gives a false positive. -/
#check @graded_module.is_module /- The following arguments become metavariables. argument 5: {Ïƒ' : Type u_6}, argument 8: (ğ“ : Î¹ â†’ Ïƒ') -/
Bottom line though is that I don't know how to fix it.
Yes, Lean complains because it can't reliably figure out the ğ“. I would just put in a letI := GradedModule.isModule ğ“ ğ“œ.

If one of the type class assumptions reliably determines the ğ“, you could mark that argument of that type class as outparam. But I think there is more than one choice for the scalar multiplication usually.
